title: Interlocking interval topology
summary: In mathematics, and especially general topology, the interlocking interval topology is an example of a topology on the set SÂ := R+ \ Z+, i.e. the set of all positive real numbers that are not positive whole numbers.[1] To give the set S a topology means to say which subsets of S are "open", and to do so in a way that the following axioms are met:[2]
